Edited November 29, 2013 by gtmattz

For Being dead, it sure looks alive ... Look at the width of the tail.compared to the diameter of the sun

Trouble is that, on the way in, it was bright enough to cause very noticeable saturation spikes in the image. And even then it was only determined to have an apparent magnitude of somewhere on the order of +0.5.

It may well have survived better than they first thought, but its prospects of becoming the "comet of the century" seem dim.

ISON is definitely disrupted, but something definitely made it out. What sort of coma and tail it'll release is very, very much up for debate.

Pity; it's due to make its closest approach on my Dad's 80th birthday, and a big showy comet would've been great help marking the occasion.

-- Steve
I guess for now all we can do is wait and hope... In the next few days we should know more.

Instead of one big one I'm sure well see a line of small comets now. Hopefully atleast.. something had to make it through.

Edit: Apparently the comet lives. That article changed its title. I gotta try and figure out how to download SOHO images.
